questions.text: Methylxanthines, such as theophylline and caffeine, are used for the treatment of apnea of prematurity. Of the following, the most likely mechanism(s) of methylxanthine use in premature infants is (are): i. Decreases hypoxic depression of breathing ii. Decreases periodic breathing iii. Enhances diaphragmatic activity iv. Improves carbon dioxide sensitivity v. Increases minute ventilation
A 28 week baby 800gm is born in your hospital by normal delivery. There is mild distress. What should be next and the best intervention for this baby?

A primigravida 38-year old woman at 36 weeks’ gestation is admitted for induction of labor for intrauterine fetal growth restriction, with an estimated fetal weight at the 1st percentile and no interval growth over the previous week. Subsequently, the fetus is noted to have category II heart rate tracings. The neonatology team is present for the delivery. The male infant emerges limp and apneic, and is brought to the radiant warmer. He does not respond to the initial steps of warmth, drying and tactile stimulation. At 30 seconds of age, the infant’s heart rate is 80 beats per minute and positive-pressure ventilation is initiated. What is the primary measure of adequate initial ventilation in the infant in this vignette?

An infant born at 32 weeks’ gestation is admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. At 5 hours of age, the infant has tachypnea, nasal flaring, and retractions. The neonatology nurse practitioner also appreciates expiratory grunting and central cyanosis. A chest radiograph is shown below: The infant described in this vignette most likely has:

You are asked to evaluate a 2-week old infant with jaundice, pale colored stools, and dark urine. The infant's mother is hepatitis B surface antigen negative and the infant received the Hepatitis B vaccine at birth. You are concerned about cholestasis and order fractionated bilirubin levels, hepatic enzyme levels, and a coagulation panel. The infant has an elevated direct bilirubin level, mildly elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST), and abnormal coagulation parameters You suspect that the infant has biliary atresia. What is the next step in the evaluation of the infant in this vignette?

A 43-year-old primigravida woman presented in labor and feeling a decrease in fetal movements. The fetal tracing is flat, prompting an emergent cesarean delivery. After birth, the baby girl requires resuscitation with intubation, chest compressions, epinephrine, and volume. Her Apgar scores are 1, 3, and 4 at 1, 5, and 10 minutes, respectively. The cord pH is 6.82 in the umbilical artery and 6.93 in the umbilical vein. While being observed in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU), the infant has a seizure. The most common timing of seizure activity in this infant with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is:

options.label: B
options.text: Within the first 24 hours of life

questions.correct_answer: B. Within the first 24 hours of life

questions.text: A nurse in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit asks the neonatology fellow to evaluate an infant because she is concerned about a new diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The male patient was born at 26 weeks' gestational age and is now 2 weeks of age. His clinical course has been complicated by: • Surfactant deficiency treated with intubation and surfactant administration • A large patent ductus arteriosus with left atrial dilation treated with three doses of indomethacin • Mild intestinal dysmotility leading to slow advancement of nasogastric feedings • Apnea of prematurity treated with caffeine • Sepsis evaluation with antibiotic therapy for 2 days and negative blood culture results The baby is currently on continuous positive airway pressure with a positive end-expiratory pressure of 6-cm H2O. He is being fed 50 ml./kg/day of his mother's pumped breast milk without additives. He is receiving the remainder of his maintenance fluid requirement in the form of total parenteral nutrition. After reviewing the infant's new clinical symptoms with the nurse and examining the baby, the fellow is also concerned about a diagnosis of NEC in this baby. Of the following, early clinical finding(s) consistent with a diagnosis of NEC is (are):
Of the following the radiographic finding in this film most consistent with the diagnosis of NEC is:
Of the following, the electrolyte abnormality that is often found in infants born to women with diabetes mellitus is:
Of the following the anomaly that occurs during the second half of gestation in infants of diabetic mothers is:
What is 3 minute target spO2 for newborns in right upper limb?
What is the iv dose of epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation in mg/kg?
Which is most common anomaly in infants of DM mothers?
The most common region of the brain affected by periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is:

options.label: C
options.text: Periventricular white matter dorsolateral to the external angles of the lateral ventricles

questions.correct_answer: C. Periventricular white matter dorsolateral to the external angles of the lateral ventricles

questions.text: The pathogenesis of periventricular leukomalacia in preterm infants includes:

options.label: A
options.text: Compression on the developing white matter following intraventricular hemorrhage

options.label: B
options.text: Oligodendrocyte progenitor cells present in the periventricular area that are especially susceptible to free radical injury

options.label: C
options.text: Poor vascular supply to the periventricular white matter

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant is seen for his health supervision visit. He is tracking, smiling socially, and holding his head up without support for a few seconds. He has a 4-year-old sister who is developmentally normal. His mother’s brother died at 20 years of age with complications related to a muscle disease. He had calf hypertrophy and used his hands to crawl from a lying to a standing position. He required the use of a wheelchair by 10 years of age. The mother reports that she has no muscle weakness or cramps. The mother underwent echocardiography 5 years ago for chest pain that showed mild dilated cardiomyopathy felt to be related to her brother’s disorder. The parents are concerned about their son’s risk of experiencing the same condition.Of the following, the MOST accurate percentage change that this infant has the same condition as his uncle is

A 4-month-old infant is seen in the office as a new patient. She has a seizure disorder that is controlled by medication. She is doing well, and her mother has no concerns regarding her eating, growth, of development. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable, except for multiple hypopigmented macules. Her father has similar hypopigmented lesions on the skin, a benign brain tumor, and cysts. Of the following the MOST appropriate study for this infant is

options.label: B
options.text: Echocardiography to evaluate for ventricular septal defect(s)

options.label: C
options.text: Electrocardiography to evaluate for atrioventricular block

options.label: D
options.text: Electrocardiography to evaluate for Prolonged QT interval

questions.correct_answer: A. Echocardiography to evaluate for rhabdomyomas

questions.text: You are caring for a female infant with a seizure disorder. She was born full-term after an uneventful pregnancy. There is no family history of seizure disorders. Her seizures were initially noted by her pediatrician at the two-week visit, and have been difficult to manage. She received a phenobarbital load and maintenance phenobarbital, and levetriacetam was added when her EEG demonstrated ongoing seizure activity. She has had a persistent moderate lactic acidosis. Her MRI revealed focal, bilateral lesions in the basal ganglia. On exam, she is hypotonic and thin, with long curly eyelashes. She was diagnosed with Leigh Syndrome. If the causative mutation of the infant in this vignette is not somatic, the most likely mode of inheritance is:

An 8-year-old boy is seen for a health supervision visit. He is in the third grade in a special education classroom. His parents report that he walked at 2 years, started putting 2 words together at 3 years, and has been receiving physical, occupational, and speech therapy for his entire life. His birth and postnatal history are significant for hypotonia and failure to thrive, and he required a gastrointestinal tube for feeding. His parents are currently concerned about his excessive eating behaviour. His weight and height are at the 98th and 2nd percentile, respectively. He has almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, small hands and feet, and a small penis with a hypoplastic scrotum. The remainder of his physical examination findings are normal. Of the following, the MOST appropriate therapy for this condition is

options.label: A
options.text: Glucocorticoid therapy in the first year after birth with nutrition management

options.label: B
options.text: Growth hormone therapy in the first year after birth with nutrition management

options.label: C
options.text: Growth hormone therapy in the first year after birth with supplementation of carnitine

options.label: D
options.text: Levothyroxine therapy in the first year after birth with nutrition management

questions.correct_answer: B. Growth hormone therapy in the first year after birth with nutrition management

questions.text: The most likely inheritance pattern for a condition with an enzyme deficiency is:
Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) can occur to which of the following cytologic mechanisms?

A neonate is diagnosed with supravalvular subaortic stenosis. Upon examination you note hypoplastic nails, prominent lips, and a stellate iris pattern. Which of the following microdeletions is responsible for this neonate’s likely syndrome?
Which of the following disorder is NOT commonly caused by a microdeletion?

You are called to examine a male infant born at 35 6/7 weeks’ gestation. The baby had been born by caesarean section for non-reassuring fetal heart tracing 6 days ago to a woman with no prenatal care. The Newborn screening program just called the nursery to report that the infant had tested positive for severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) diagnosed by decreased TRECs (T Cell Receptor Excision Circles). You examination reveals the following: • Weight = 2.8 kg • Posteriorly rotated ears • Soft palate cleft • Loud systolic ejection murmur in the upper left parasternal area The bedside nurse informs you that the infant is in the hospital because of poor feeding associated with regurgitation. In the last 24 hours, the baby has had 2 episodes of cyanosis, which resolved spontaneously with stimulation and position change. You order laboratory and radiographic testing with results as follows: • WBC = 5000/µliter (polysegmented neutrophils 85%, lymphocytes 12%, metamyelocytes 1%, bands 1%, eosinophils 1%) • Hematocrit=50% • Platelet count=240,000 cells/ µliter • Na=140 mEq/L, K = 3.5 mEq/L, Chloride = 105 mEq/L, HCO3 =18 mEq/L • Calcium =4.5 mg/dL, phosphrus = 3mg/dL, Magnesium = 1.2 mg/dL • Chest radiograph: decreased pulmonary vasculature with a prominent right heart apex and no visible thymic shadow Which of the following would be likely diagnosis to explain this infant’s finding?

options.label: D
options.text: False-positive SCID screen as a result of prematurity

questions.text: A female infant is born at 33 weeks’ gestation and has difficulty with oral feedings despite reaching 42 weeks’ postmenstrual gestational age. On exam, she has notable generalized hypotonia and a weak suck. She also has arthrogryposis of her legs. Otherwise her vital signs and exam are reassuring. You notice when you speak with the baby’s mother that the mother has a paucity of facial movements during your conversation. Of the following options, the most likely reason why this infant is more severely affected than her mother is:
The inheritance of Temple syndrome is
Inheritance of Wang syndrome is
What is the inheritance of Pearson syndrome, pancreatic insufficiency and pancytopenia?
When can a child speak around 10 words, identifies 1 or more parts of body, complains of being wet or soiled?
When can a When can a child run well, imitates horizontal strokes, handles spoon well, help to undress?child run well, imitates horizontal strokes, handles spoon well, help to undress?
When can a child repeat 3 numbers, plays in parallel with other children?
When can a child start role playing and goes to toilet alone?

A 15-year-old girl presents to your clinic with the complaint that she has not had menses. The girl has Tanner I breast with widely spaced nipples and no pubic or axillary hair. Her midparental height is in the 75th percentile; however, her height is well below normal, at the 3rd percentile. Her mother states that she had a history of a grade III heart murmur that has not been evaluated. Which of the following is the best next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Provide reassurance because she will likely spontaneously undergo puberty.

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a pelvic ultrasound to identify müllerian structures.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy visits your clinic with concerns about being shorter than his peers and not having a growth spurt. Of note, both his parents were late bloomers and underwent puberty late. He has been tracking along the 25 percentile, which is within 2 standard deviations of his midparental height. On examination, he has a boyish appearance. His testes are 4 ml. bilaterally with a 5-cm phallus. There is some small, coarse pubic hair. A bone age was completed and demonstrates his skeletal age is closer to an 11-year-old male. Laboratory work was also obtained but the results have not returned. Which of the following laboratory results are most consistent with your patient's findings?

options.label: B
options.text: LH, FSH. and testosterone at early pubertal levels

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated LH and elevated RESH with low testosterone

options.label: D
options.text: Low LH, low FSH, and low testosterone

options.label: E
options.text: There is insufficient information to determine this

questions.correct_answer: B. LH, FSH. and testosterone at early pubertal levels

questions.text: A 16-year-old obese male comes to your clinic for a routine physical examination. He complains about having breasts for the past year and wants to know if there is anything he can do. He previously had tenderness, which has now subsided. He denies any discharge. He is currently not on any medications and denies any illicit drug use. On examination, he has Tanner II breast with significant adipose tissue. His testes are tanner stage III (10 mL bilaterally) with normal phallus, which of the following is true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: He is a good candidate for mastectomy.

options.label: B
options.text: His breast will likely resolve with time and with weight loss management.

options.label: C
options.text: He most likely has a Sertoli cell tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: He most likely has partial androgen insensitivity syndrome.

options.label: E
options.text: He most likely is taking anabolic steroids.

questions.correct_answer: B. His breast will likely resolve with time and with weight loss management.

questions.text: 85% of children learn bladder control by ……………yrs

A 6 month old infant began to vomit and ceased to gain weight. At 9 months he was again readmitted in the hospital. Routine examination and lab tests were normal, but after one week he came drowsy, his temperature rose to 39 degree C, and had hepatomegaly. Since the child could not take milk, even by tube feeds, intravenous glucose was given, and he improved his sensorium.Urine analysis showed very high glutamine and uracil.What is the enzyme deficiency?

For most lysosomal storage disorders, carrier identification and prenatal diagnosis are available; a specific diagnosis is essential to permit genetic counselling. Which of the following disorders is X-linked?

A 7 months old boy has been healthy and developing normally since birth. His mother now reports that he has decreased eye contact with her, even during feedings. The infant also startles very easily when there is a loud noise in the house. Of the following, the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the etiology of these findings is the measurement of:

A 3 yr old boy was normal at birth but developed progressive coarsening of the face and developmental delay. In addition to coarse facies and mental retardation, the physical examination reveals a cardiac systolic regurgitant murmur, hepatomegaly, joint stiffness, and short stature. CT scan reveals hydrocephalus. These is no corneal clouding. All affected family members have been boys. The most likely diagnosis is:
Hurler disease is characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:
The best test for universal screening of metabolic disorders is
RDA for vitamin D for infants is …………IU/day
Breast milk has…………IU/Litre
Which of the following would be the plasma osmolality of a child with plasma Na+ 125 mEq/l, glucose of 108 mg/dl, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 140 mg/dl?
The low osmolarity ORS has ……meq/l of Sodium
The low osmolarity ORS has …gm of NaCI in the packet
Supplementation should be given to all children with acute diarrhea

A previously healthy 7-mo-old white baby boy presents one summer day with a temperature of 41.1?C, a pulse of 190/min, a respiratory rate of 70 breaths/min, and a blood pressure of 65/20 mm Hg. He has a 1-day history of diarrhea (five stools in 24 hr) and is now unresponsive to verbal commands or painful stimuli. The most appropriate initial therapy is:
questions.correct_answer: D. Administration of normal saline (20-40 mL/kg)

questions.text: The fetus lives in a relatively hypoxemic environment. The intrauterine circulation consists of two parallel systems that are not completely separated because of mixing at the atrial and ductal levels.The following vessels/chambers have oxygen saturations from HIGHEST to LOWEST:

options.label: A
options.text: Left ventricle>umbilical vein> superior vena cava > right ventricle

options.label: B
options.text: Superior vena cava > umbilical vein >right ventricle >left ventricle

options.label: C
options.text: Umbilical vein> left ventricle> right ventricle> superior vena cava

options.label: D
options.text: Umbilical vein> superior vena cava> right ventricle > left ventricle

questions.correct_answer: C. Umbilical vein> left ventricle> right ventricle> superior vena cava

questions.text: An infant born at 25 weeks’ gestation is now 6 days old and a continuous murmur is auscultated on exam that is concerning for a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Which of the following factors does NOT cause dilation of the PDA?
The fetal ductus arteriosus remains patent, in part, because of high circulating levels of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) and PGI1.The source of these circulating prostaglandins is the:

A term infant is delivered vaginally and has an Apgar score of 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. At approximately 15 minutes of life, the infant develops respiratory distress evident by grunting, flaring and retractions. Pulse oximetry in the right arm reveals an oxygen saturation of 50%. The infant is placed in a 100% oxygen hood and O2 saturations improve to 65%. The infant is intubated and O2 saturations remain at 65%. Echocardiography reveals total anomalous pulmonary veins that appear to be obstructive. The medical student rotating in the NICU asks the neonatologist to explain the likely pathway of this infant's pulmonary veins.Which type of total anomalous pulmonary veins is most commonly associated with obstructive vessels?

You are called to the delivery room to evaluate a cyanotic term neonate. On arrival, you note a severely cyanotic female neonate without respiratory distress. The infant has 2+ distal pulses bilaterally, no murmur, and a loud, single S2. The chest radiograph shows a normal heart size and a narrow mediastinum. You contact a cardiologist and order intravenous prostaglandin therapy. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis. What is the likely next step in the management of this infant?

To evaluate a persistently cyanotic infant in the first day of life, the neonatology fellow requests an echocardiogram that reveals truncus arteriosus. The fellow sends chemistry values on the infant which are remarkable only for a low serum calcium concentration. The fellow’s physical examination of the infant reveals hypertelorism, micrognathia, and a cleft palate. The team suspects a genetic syndrome.Which chromosome is likely to be affected?

You are called to the emergency room for a 2-month-old infant who is cyanotic. When you arrive, you see that her saturation on pulse oximetry is 77%. She is crying loudly and appears irritable. Her heart rate is 176 beats/min, and her blood pressure is normal for her age. She is warm and well perfused, though dusky. One examination, you cannot hear a murmur. Her parents report that she has been febrile at home and has been vomiting since yesterday. They also tell you she has been diagnosed with TOF and is scheduled for surgery next month. The emergency room physician has already placed the infant on 3 L of 100% oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and obtained IV access. Of the following, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this infant?

A 7-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department (ED) with 5 days of fever. On examination, his knee appears swollen, and a holosystolic murmur is heard at the cardiac apex. He complained of a sore throat a few weeks ago and of elbow pain a few days ago. But his parent denies a recent history of cough, nasal congestion, or rash. Vital signs are stable. The next best step to establish a diagnosis is:

options.label: B
options.text: Culture the oropharynx and order an antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer

options.label: C
options.text: Treat the patient with 2 g/kg of IVIG

options.label: D
options.text: Order antibody titers to Borrelia burgdorferi

questions.correct_answer: B. Culture the oropharynx and order an antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer

questions.text: In a patient with suspected Kawasaki disease, which of the following physical examination findings would lead you strongly consider an alternative diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral conjunctivitis that is not limbal sparing

options.label: C
options.text: Morbilliform rash involving the face and extremities

questions.text: A 7-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room (ER) with severe colicky abdominal pain. He recently completed a 10-day course of amoxicillin for streptococcal pharyngitis. At the end of the antibiotic course, he developed red spots around his feet, which have since spread up his legs to his thighs and buttocks. He has not wanted to walk due to pain and swelling in his feet. His vital signs include a temperature of 38.0?C, heart rate of 112 beats/min, and blood pressure of 104/70. On examination you note raised, nonblanching red to purple papules concentrated on his lower legs and feet, edema of the dorsum of his hands and feet, as well as abdominal tenderness to palpation. His initial laboratory results demonstrate a white blood cell count of 11,000/mm3, hemoglobin of 12.5 g/dL, platelet count of 230,000/mm3, serum creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL, and international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.0. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Send Rickettsia serologies and start doxycycline.

options.label: B
options.text: Consult radiology for a barium enema.

options.label: E
options.text: Consult cardiology for a transthoracic echocardiogram.

questions.text: A 10 yrs old child from Africa presents to you with fever since 15 days, and pain abdomen since 5 days. He also has a rash over his face and conjunctival inflammation. On examination- HR-150/minute, BP 90/60mmHg. Sp02 93 percent room air. He is on BiPAP support on ventilator. His Covid-19 IgG is positive. In addition to supportive care, what should be the next step?
What drug should be added in children with multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children with covid who have persistent fever despite ivIg?

A full term male infant has prolonged indirect hyperbilirubinemia, a large posterior fontanel, hypotonia, and feeding difficulties. The neonatology fellow suspects that the infant has congenital hypothyroidism. Laboratory evaluation reveals a low thyroxine concentration and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone.The most likely cause for this infant’s hypothyroidism is:

A 14-day old male infant is brought to the Emergency Department because of difficulty feeding, vomiting, and lethargy. Physical examination reveals temperature=37?C, heart rate=190 beats per minute, blood pressure=55/30 (mean=34) mm Hg, and respiratory rate=60 breaths per minute. The infant’s anterior fontanel is sunken and his skin turgor is poor with a capillary refill time of 5 seconds. Which of the following laboratory findings are MOST consistent with the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia resulting from 21-hydroxylase deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium=124 mEq/L, potassium=6.2 mEq/L, chloride=86 mEq/L

questions.correct_answer: A. Sodium=124 mEq/L, potassium=6.2 mEq/L, chloride=86 mEq/L

questions.text: What is the most common clinical presentation of an infant with congenital hypothyroidism?

An infant is about to be delivered at 38 weeks’ gestation by Cesarean delivery. A pediatric resident interested in pursuing endocrinology is attending the delivery with a neonatologist. She is interested in learning more about the physiological function of the thyroid gland and asks about normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels after birth.Of the following, the pattern that most likely corresponds to an infant’s serum TSH concentration is:
questions.correct_answer: B. Peaks at 30 minutes of age

questions.text: You are taking care of a 1-week old female infant born at 31 weeks’ gestation. You just heard that the newborn state screen revealed a slightly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) level. The baby is clinically stable and receiving feedings with unfortified maternal milk via a nasogastric tube. Reviewing her laboratory results, you notice that the infant has mild hyponatremia. ON physical examination, you notice a slightly enlarged clitoris. The most preferred approach in managing the infant in this vignette is to:

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately start the baby on stress steroids

options.label: B
options.text: Discuss with the parents that the infant’s mild hyponatremia is likely related a low sodium concentration in the breast milk

options.label: C
options.text: Not take any further action as the newborn state screen often yields false-positive results for congenital adrenal hyperplasia in premature babies

options.label: D
options.text: Reassure the parents the slightly enlarged clitoris is a normal variant of prematurity

options.label: E
options.text: Send a repeat newborn state screen as well as electrolytes and a 17-OHP level

questions.correct_answer: E. Send a repeat newborn state screen as well as electrolytes and a 17-OHP level

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is the most common cause of virilization in females. 21 ?-hydroxylase deficiency accounts for 95% of these causes. Which of the following plasma steroid profiles is MOST TYPICAL of the salt wasting form of 21 ?-hydroxylase deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated: 11-deoxycorticosterone and aldosterone; Variable: 17 hydroxyprogesterone; Decreased: dehydroepiandrosterone and renin

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated: 17 hydroxyprogesterone dehydropiandrosterone and 11-deoxycorticosterone; Decreased: aldosterone, and renin

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated: 17-hydroxyprogesterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, and renin: Decreased: aldosterone

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated: 17-hydroxyprogesterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, and renin: Norma: 11-deoxycorticosterone and aldosterone

options.label: E
options.text: Elevated: dehydroepiandrosterone and renin: Decreased: 17-hydroxyprogesterone, 11-deoxycorticosterone and aldosterone

questions.correct_answer: C. Elevated: 17-hydroxyprogesterone, dehydroepiandrosterone, and renin: Decreased: aldosterone

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-week-old male is brought to an emergency room by his parents after he was noted as having decreased activity and oral intake at home. Upon arrival. He is found to be quite lethargic and is rushed to the resuscitation bay. His vital signs are as follows: heart rate (HR) 165 beats/min. blood pressure (BP) 40/20 mm Hg. respiratory rate (RR) 30 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation (SpO2)99% In room air. On examination. He is pale and cries weakly throughout the resuscitation. Intravenous access is obtained, and he is provided with a 20 mL/kg normal saline fluid bolus. His initial laboratory work is as follows: ? Na 130 mEg/L ? K 5.8 meq/L ? Cl 100 mmol/L ? C O2, 18 mmol/L ? BUN 20 mg/dL ? Cr 0.6mg/dL ? Glucose 75 mg/dL ? WBC 10.0 billion/L ? Hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL ? Platelets 300 billion/L Given the above presentation, which of the following interventions is most indicated at this time?

As a physician in the newborn nursery, you are evaluating a recently delivered full-term female Infant. Her mother received adequate prenatal care and had unremarkable prenatal testing and uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. You notice on examination, however, that there appears to be clitoral hypertrophy and rugated labia. With concern for CAH, you test for the most common cause of CAH. Which of the following is the most appropriate test?

You are seeing a newborn male in your clinic for his first visit since being discharged from the hospital. In preparing for his visit, you find that the results of his newborn screen are consistent with CAH. While explaining the diagnosis to his parents, you are asked whether the diagnosis could have been made earlier, in the newborn nursery. Which of the following is the best response to this question?

options.label: A
options.text: Most males with CAH are born with ambiguous genitalia, which could have been noticed at the time of birth.

options.label: B
options.text: Males with CAH are unlikely to have obvious physical examination findings at birth and are therefore more likely to present with adrenal insufficiency.

options.label: C
options.text: Females are more likely to be diagnosed with CAH at birth due to the presence of clitoral hypertrophy and testes

options.label: D
options.text: Because not all forms of CAH may cause obvious physical findings at birth, newborn screening is a definitive tool by which to diagnose these disorders.

options.label: E
options.text: It is more common for those with CAH to present during adolescence with precoclous puberty and early pubarche.

questions.correct_answer: B. Males with CAH are unlikely to have obvious physical examination findings at birth and are therefore more likely to present with adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which hormone contributes to the development of macrosomia among infants of diabetic mothers?
Which of the following is the best studied and the best biomarker for AKI?
What is the drug of choice for atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome in children and adults?

A 3 yr old girl presents to the emergency department with anasarca. The urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and is negative for blood. Serum albumin in 1.2 mg/dL and serum creatinine is 0.4 mg/dL. The most likely diagnosis is:
What is the drug of choice for steroid resistant FSGS?

A 15-year-old adolescent is brought to the emergency department for a new-onset generalized tonic-clonic seizure that occurred while asleep. She was having a sleepover party and had stayed up until 3 am. Around 7 am, her friend found her unresponsive with generalized shaking, her eyes rolled up and open, and foaming at the mouth. The event lasted approximately 2 minutes before self-resolving. On arrival at the emergency department, the girl is drowsy but arousable. She has otherwise normal neurologic findings. Her mother reports that the adolescent has had several episodes of staring spells over the past few years which she attributed to her daughter ignoring her. Over the past year, she has periodically complained of “spasms” where her hand will suddenly jump or jerk. She denies substance use, recent or intercurrent illnesses, or trauma. There is no family history of seizures. Of the following, the MOST likely diagnosis is

A 4-month-old infant is seen in the office as a new patient. She has a seizure disorder that is controlled by medication. She is doing well, and her mother has no concerns regarding her eating, growth, or development. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable, except for multiple hypopigmented macules. Her father has similar hypopigmented lesions on the skin, a benign brain tumor, and renal cysts. What could be the cause of cysts in her father?
In the previous questions, what would be drug of choice for seizure in the infant?

An 8-year-old girl is seen in the office for concerns about her academic performance. Her teachers note that she tends to daydream and is struggling to stay focused on her work; at times they find it difficult to get her attention. Her parents report that sometimes they must ask her a question 2 or 3 times before receiving a response. She is an otherwise healthy child and when engaged in a task she is able to complete it. The girl reports that she finds herself “losing time” Periodically throughout the day which sometimes makes it hard to stay focused on her activity. In the office, the girl is sitting quietly next to her parents. She intermittently stares, then rapidly returns to the conversation. Her general physical examination findings are unremarkable. Neurologic findings are normal, though during the examination, she has an episode of staring, during which she is not responsive to direction for a few seconds. Of the following the best next management step for this girl is

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain

questions.text: Most common cause of meningitis in children more than 1 month of life in the developed world?
Most common cause of meningitis is children more than 3 yrs of life in the developed world?

In regions where penicillin-resistant pneumococci are prevent, patients who are strongly suspected of having bacterial meningitis should receive which of the following antimicrobial agents added to ceftriaxone or cefotaxime as empirical antimicrobial therapy?

A 13 mo old previously heathy child presents on New Year’s Eve with a 2-day history of fever, lethargy, and irritability. Earlier this afternoon he began to have twitching movements of his left arm and on the left side of his face. His immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination reveals fever with a temperature of 39?C and left-sided weakness, with no rashes. Examination of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals 70 WBCs/mm3 with 85% lymphocytes, 400 RBCs/mm3, protein of 140 mg/dL glucose 80 mg/dL and negative results on Gram stain. CT brain is shown below. The diagnostic study most likely to identify a treatable illness in a timely fashion is

options.label: B
options.text: Herpes simplex virus polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay

options.label: D
options.text: Comparison of maternal and infant antibody titers

questions.correct_answer: B. Herpes simplex virus polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay

questions.text: A premature infant is undergoing mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress syndrome. Peak inspiratory pressure is 32 cm H2O, positive and-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is 5 cm H2O, and ventilatory rate is 30 breaths/min. The infant has decreased peripheral perfusion, manifested as a prolonged capillary refill time and weak arterial pulses. The central venous pressure measured at the right atrium with an umbilical venous catheter is 2 mm Hg (or approximately 3 cm H2O). PaO2 is 80 mm Hg, and PaCO2 is 38 mm Hg. Which of the following measures is most likely to result in an improvement in this infant’s perfusion?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduce peak inspiratory pressure to 28 cm H2O

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer 10 mL/kg of normal saline

questions.text: A previously healthy 6 yr old child presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of malaise, poor oral intake, diarrhea, and decreased urine output. Physical examination reveals tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, and sunken eyes. Results of initial laboratory studies include BUN 65 mg/dL. Potassium 5.5 mEq/L, bicarbonate 14 mEq/L, and serum creatinine 3.0 mg/dL. The most appropriate next step in treatment is to:

options.label: B
options.text: Run intravenous replacement fluid at rate to replace insensible losses plus urine output

options.label: C
options.text: Give NaHCO3 1 mEq/kg IV to correct acidosis

options.label: D
options.text: Administer normal saline 20 mL/kg bolus over 30 min

questions.correct_answer: D. Administer normal saline 20 mL/kg bolus over 30 min

questions.text: What is the best route to administer fluids for shock in a 1000gm preterm newborn baby?
What is SAM?
What is the maximum protein in g/kg which we can give in catch up phase of SAM rehabilitation?
How much of RUTF should a child < 4 kg drink to pass appetite test?

A 9 day old neonate, born by vaginal delivery to a 21 yr old healthy woman, is presented with fever, lethargy, and poor feeding. There are no diagnostic findings on physical examination, and results of sepsis evaluation, including a CBC and cerebrospinal fluid studies, are unremarkable. Ampicillin and cefotaxime are begun. Two days later all bacterial cultures are negative but the child’s clinical condition worsens, with falling blood pressure, decreased level of consciousness, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. The indicated change in treatment is:
This 4 months old child has abnormal movements particularly in drowsiness and arousal. The following is his EEG. What is your diagnosis?
What is the best drug for the above child?
The CT scan show below show which form of congenital hydrocephalus?

A 20-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents. She developed upper respiratory symptoms 2 days ago but now has “noisier breathing”. Upon examination she has cough and loud stridor. A radiograph shows a tapered narrowing of the immediate subglottic airway. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

You are evaluating a 5-year-old boy for the first time in your practice. He presents for a regular checkup. You notice that the patient has digital clubbing. On further questioning. You find out that he has had recurrent pneumonias (five to six episodes every year) and that his weight has always been in the 10th percentile. Which of the following laboratory tests in most appropriate to order during additional evaluation of this patient?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for a new well-child visit. Height is in the 3rd percentile, and weight is in the 1st percentile. During the interview, the parents say that the patient has been treated multiple times since infancy because of sinus infections and pneumonia. They also note that her stools are generally loose, greasy, and resembling mucus. During physical examination is remarkable for diffuse polyphonic wheezing. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following studies is most effective to determine the diagnosis in the patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Culture of aspirate from the trachea

questions.text: A 1 month old child, weighing 2.5kg comes to PHC with fever and respiratory difficulty. On Exam: lethargic, RR=66/minute, no chest retractions. What is next appropriate step?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe oral antibiotic, warn for danger signs, send home

options.label: B
options.text: Give intravenous antibiotics and refer to higher centre

questions.correct_answer: B. Give intravenous antibiotics and refer to higher centre

questions.text: What is the most common cause of pneumonia in India between 3 months- 3 years?
Which of the following pharmacotherapies is most beneficial for G551D patients?

options.label: D
options.text: No therapies are available for this specific mutation

questions.text: Which of the following agent is not a CFTR trafficking corrector?

options.label: D
options.text: None of these is a corrector
